en.pressContinue: Press the next button to continue.
en.tutorial00: Hello fellow students! Welcome to the Rocketo: Division Videogame!
en.tutorial01: Here you will learn about strategies to solve certain kind of division problems such as partitioning division
en.tutorial02: My name is Rocketo and I will be your guide throughout the game.
en.tutorial03: So, let's start. Before we begin you must understand basic divisions and how to they work.
en.tutorial04: The reasoning behind is quite simple, for example on this equation: 6 ÷ 734
en.tutorial05: We have to figure out how many groups of 6 does 734 contain.
en.tutorial06: To start, let's find a friendly number, a high number multiplied by 6, with an easy number like 100. 6 times 100 equals to 600, so we are getting close.
en.tutorial07: Next we substract with our dividiend or original number with 600 and we get 134.
en.tutorial08: Then we figure out how many groups of 6 are in 134. Now we think what number can I use to get close to that.
en.tutorial09: 20 groups of 6 fit into 134, don't forget to substract.
en.tutorial10: 134 - 120 equals 14. Now how many groups of six fit into 14? the answer is simple, 2.
en.tutorial11: Finally we count every group of six we worked so far and add them up. The answer is 122, and we got a remainder of 2.
en.tutorial12: Now let's solve a problem with my help. Let's divide 5 ÷ 940.
en.tutorial13: Remember, we must get close to 940 using groups of 5 by multiplying a number in multiples of high round numbers, such as 100. (Remember to click the Number Box then type the number on the keyboard)
en.tutorial14: Correct! 500 is the closest number to 940.
en.tutorial17: Now we find a number closer to 440, since we already used multiplying 5 by 100, we go to the next lower number to fit into.
en.tutorial18: Correct! 5 x 80 equals 400 which is the closest to 440.
en.tutorial19: Don't forget, now we substract 440 - 400 to continue our division problem.
en.tutorial21: Finally we find the closest number to 40 with groups of 5.
en.tutorial23: Now we add up all groups of 5 used to solve our division.
en.tutorial24: Yes we did it! The final answer to the division is 188 with a remainder of 0.
en.tutorial25: I think that your are all set to go for our first challenge. This time I will not be there to help you. But I trust that you can do it.
en.tutorial26: Let's start with an easy one, solve this division problem: 2 ÷ 24
en.tutorial27: Congratulations! It seems you are learning fast! That is the correct answer, now let's move to another problem. Just a bit more challenging!
en.tutorial28: Now try to solve the next division problem: 2 ÷ 243
en.tutorial29: You are getting pretty good at divisions! That's awesome!
en.tutorial30: Remember the first challenge? 2 ÷ 24? Let's make it harder, solve 2 ÷ 2400. Note that is the same reasoning as making the first challenge.
en.tutorial31: You did it! Congratulations! See that even if the dividend is 4 digits long, it is related to the 2 digits long problem.
en.tutorial32: Let's continue to the next subject: Division Area Models.
en.tutorial33: I'll use this example problem to start, 2 ÷ 240.
en.tutorial34: Let's start by interpeting this problem into a division area model, make a rectangle where it's total area is the dividend, 240.
en.tutorial35: And one side of it's dimensions is 2, and the other dimension is the unknown that we are looking for.
en.tutorial36: So to solve this we must start partitioning or decomposing the dividend (240) into chunks that are divisible by the divisor (2).
en.tutorial37: Then using our place value strategies we know that 2 times a hundred will give me 200. But still we need more to build up to the diviend, 240.
en.tutorial38: So we move on to tens this time, so we will use 2 chunks of 10 to add up 40.
en.tutorial39: Now that we have the total area divided into chunks, we see that the bottom dimension is the sum of 100 + 10 + 10.
en.tutorial40: So the final answer to our division is 120, which is the unknown area we are looking for.
en.tutorial41: For our first practice problem we will use area division model to solve: 3 ÷ 366. Don't worry, I will guide you throughout this division problem.
en.tutorial42: Remember to visualize a rectangle which it's total area is the same as the dividend (366) and one of it's dimensions is the divisor (3).
en.tutorial43: Then we start with a higher number to start multiplying with the divisor to build up to our unknown number such as 100.
en.tutorial44: Correct! 300 is the bigger number we need to get closer to our dividend.
en.tutorial45: Now we must continue to get closer to the remaining numbers of the dividend, 66.
en.tutorial46: Let's continue with a number close to 66, what would be the next chunk divisible by 3 close to 66? Remember to use numbers multiple by 1 or 10.
en.tutorial47: Great! Now we are getting closer, But I believe you need another exact same chunk to build up.
en.tutorial48: Awesome! we've tackled 2 groups of 30 which gives us 60.
en.tutorial49: Finally we need to figure out how many groups of 3 we need to build up to the remaining numbers of the dividend, 6.
en.tutorial50: Great Job! now we still need one more since we only have a 3 left.
en.tutorial51: We are almost there! Now that we have all our total area covered it's time to sum it up to get our unknown number.
en.tutorial52: You did it! Contratulations! The final answer is 122!
en.tutorial53: Now you are ready for the Division Area Model challenges! Don't worry you will start with easy problems first.
en.tutorial55: Allright! You've solved it! The final answer is 23!
en.tutorial56: I will ramp up the difficulty just a bit, now solve 4 ÷ 852.
en.tutorial57: Awesome! Final answer is 213, you rock!
en.tutorial58: And the final division area model problem is: 9 ÷ 1917.
en.tutorial59: Great Job! Final answer is 213, same as the previous problem!
en.tutorial60: You did it! You passed all main challenges, there is one final challenge mini game. It's completely optional. Do you want to start the final challenge?

jp.readyToPlay: あなたは遊ぶ準備ができていますか？
jp.pressContinue: 続行するには '次へ'ボタンを押してください。
